General Motors produces vehicles in 37 countries that are sold under various brands that include: [[Chevrolet]], [[Buick]], [[GMC (automobile)|GMC]], [[Cadillac]], [[Holden]], [[Holden Special Vehicles|HSV]], [[Wuling Motors|Wuling]], [[Baojun]], [[FAW-GM|Jie Fang]], and [[GM Uzbekistan|Ravon]].{{cite news |title=Sales of Ravon Cars Start in Russia |url=http://ut.uz/en/business/sales_of_ravon_cars_start_in_russia |work=Uzbekistan Today |accessdate=June 28, 2016 |date=October 23, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gm.com/company/aboutGM/our_company.html |title=About Our Company |publisher=General Motors |date=November 18, 2010 |accessdate=November 28, 2013}} General Motors Company ("new GM"), continued in 2009 following the reorganization bankruptcy of '''General Motors Corporation''' ("old GM"), which became [[Motors Liquidation Company]]. The company purchased the majority of the assets, including the brand "General Motors". ==Business units== In addition to its twelve brands, General Motors also holds a 20% stake in [[Industries Mécaniques Maghrébines|IMM]], and a 77% stake in [[GM Korea]]. It also has a number of joint-ventures, including [[Shanghai GM]], [[SAIC-GM-Wuling Automobile|SAIC-GM-Wuling]] and [[FAW-GM]] in China, [[GM-AvtoVAZ]] in Russia, [[GM Uzbekistan]], [[General Motors India Private Limited|General Motors India]], [[General Motors Egypt]], and [[Isuzu Truck South Africa]]. General Motors employs 212,000 people and does business in more than 140 countries. General Motors is divided into four business segments: ''GM North America'' (GMNA), ''GM South America'' (GMSA), ''GM International Operations'' (GMIO), and ''[[GM Financial]]''.{{rp|12, 13}} The company also operates a mobility division called [[Maven (car sharing)|Maven]], which operates car-sharing services in the United States, and is studying alternatives to individual vehicle ownership.{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/05/03/gms-maven-gig-is-a-car-sharing-service-tailor-made-for-the-gig-economy/ |title=GM's Maven Gig is a car sharing service tailor-made for the gig economy |website=techcrunch.com |date=May 3, 2017 |accessdate=December 11, 2017}} [[GM Defense]] is General Motors military defense division {{cite news |url=http://www.autonews.com/article/20171009/OEM/171009800/gm-military-defense-contractor |title=General Motors establishing new military defense division |first=Michael |last=Wayland |work=Automotive News |location=US |date=October 9, 2017 |accessdate=October 16, 2018}} to cater to the needs of the military for advanced technology and propulsion systems for military vehicles. General Motors led global vehicle sales for 77 consecutive years from 1931 through 2007, longer than any other automaker, and in 2012 was among the world's largest automakers by vehicle unit sales.{{cite news |last=Galligan |first=Kathleen |title=GM again the world's largest automaker |url=http://www.freep.com/article/20120119/BUSINESS0101/120119015/GM-again-world-s-largest-automakter |work=Detroit Free Press |date=January 19, 2012 |accessdate=January 20, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160101014836/http://www.freep.com/article/20120119/BUSINESS0101/120119015/GM-again-world-s-largest-automakter |archivedate=January 1, 2016}} General Motors acts in most countries outside the U.S. via wholly owned subsidiaries, but operates in [[People's Republic of China|China]] through 10 joint ventures.{{rp|18, 96}} GM's [[OnStar]] subsidiary provides vehicle safety, security and information services.{{cite web|title=Shanghai OnStar Announces Launch Date for Services in China|url=http://www.corvetteassembly.com/media/us/en/gm/home.detail.html/content/Pages/news/us/en/2009/Oct/1029_onstar.html|website=media.gm.com}} In 2009, General Motors shed several brands, closing [[Saturn Corporation|Saturn]], [[Pontiac]], and [[Hummer]], and emerged from a government-backed [[General Motors Chapter 11 reorganization|Chapter 11 reorganization]]. In 2010, the reorganized GM made an [[initial public offering]] that was one of the world's top five largest IPOs to date, and returned to profitability later that year.{{Citation |last=Brady |first=Diane |date=February 16, 2012 |title=Record profits, but still mixed success at GM |journal=Bloomberg Businessweek |url=http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2012-02-17/record-profits-but-still-mixed-success-at-gm |accessdate=March 10, 2012 |postscript=. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120327004302/http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2012-02-17/record-profits-but-still-mixed-success-at-gm |archivedate=March 27, 2012}} ==History== {{main|History of General Motors}} General Motors Company was formed on September 16, 1908, in [[Flint, Michigan]], as a [[holding company]] controlled by [[William C. Durant]], owner of [[Buick]].{{cite web | url=http://www.gm.com/corporate/about/company.jsp| publisher=General Motors | title=History of General Motors, Company profile | accessdate=April 4, 2011}} At the beginning of the 20th century, there were fewer than 8,000 automobiles in America, and Durant had become a leading manufacturer of horse-drawn vehicles in Flint, in the 1880s and 1890s, before making his foray into the automotive industry in 1904 by purchasing the fledgling Buick Motor Company.{{cite web|url=http://www.gm.com/corporate/about/history/historyPopUp.jsp?0 |title=GM History |publisher=General Motors Company|accessdate=February 9, 2011}} GM's co-founder was [[Charles Stewart Mott]], whose carriage company was merged into Buick prior to GM's creation. Over the years, Mott became the largest single stockholder in GM, and spent his life with his [[Charles Stewart Mott Foundation|Mott Foundation]], which has benefited the city of Flint, his adopted home. GM acquired [[Oldsmobile]] later that year. In 1909, Durant brought in [[Cadillac]], [[Elmore (automobile)|Elmore]], [[Oakland (automobile)|Oakland]], and several others. Also in 1909, GM acquired the Reliance Motor Truck Company of [[Owosso, Michigan]], and the Rapid Motor Vehicle Company of [[Pontiac, Michigan]], the predecessors of [[GMC (automobile)|GMC Truck]]. Durant, along with [[Samuel McLaughlin|R. S. McLaughlin]], lost control of GM in 1910 to a bankers' trust, because of the large amount of debt taken on in its acquisitions, coupled with a collapse in new vehicle sales.{{cite web |url=http://history.gmheritagecenter.com/wiki/index.php/1910,_The_Founder_Departs_._._._for_Now |title=GM 1910 the founder departs |accessdate=December 10, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213055217/http://history.gmheritagecenter.com/wiki/index.php/1910,_The_Founder_Departs_._._._for_Now |archive-date=December 13, 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} [[File:2007 Chevrolet Suburban LT -- 07-10-2010 1.jpg|thumb| [[Chevrolet Suburban]], longest continuous production automobile nameplate{{cite news |url=http://www.motortrend.com/news/15-vehicles-with-the-longest-running-nameplate/ |title=15 Vehicles With The Longest Running Nameplate |first=Alex |last=Nishimoto |work=Motor Trend |date=February 23, 2015 |accessdate=April 21, 2016}}]] The next year, Durant started the [[Chevrolet]] Motor Car Company in the U.S., and in Canada in 1915, and through this, he secretly purchased a controlling interest in GM. Durant regained control of the company after one of the most dramatic [[proxy fight|proxy wars]] in American business history. Durant then reorganized General Motors Company into General Motors Corporation in 1916, merging Chevrolet with GM and merging General Motors of Canada Limited as an ally in 1918. Shortly thereafter, he again lost control, this time for good, after the new vehicle market collapsed. [[Alfred P. Sloan]] was picked to take charge of the corporation, and led it to its post-war global dominance when the seven manufacturing facilities operated by Chevrolet before GM acquired the company began to contribute to GM operations. These facilities were added to the individual factories that were exclusive to Cadillac, Buick, Oldsmobile, Oakland, and other companies acquired by GM. This unprecedented growth of GM would last into the early 1980s, when it employed 349,000 workers and operated 150 assembly plants.{{citation needed|date=February 2017}} ===Chapter 11 bankruptcy=== {{Main|General Motors Chapter 11 reorganization}} [[File:14 Buick LaCrosse (14344035480).jpg|thumb|[[Buick LaCrosse#Second generation .282010.E2.80.932016.29|2nd generation Buick LaCrosse]], an example of GM's revival following its restructuring in the aftermath of the [[Great Recession]]{{cite web|url=http://www.popularmechanics.com/cars/reviews/a4429/4325072/|title=2010 Buick LaCrosse Test Drive: Can New 30-MPG Buick Sedan Revive the Brand?|work=Popular Mechanics|accessdate=March 22, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/buick-big-in-china-seeks-to-recapture-us-glory/|title=Buick, Big in China, Seeks to Recapture U.S. Glory|work=CBS News|date=March 23, 2010|accessdate=March 22, 2016}}]] On July 10, 2009, General Motors emerged from government backed [[Chapter 11, Title 11, United States Code|Chapter 11]] reorganization after an initial filing on June 8, 2009.{{cite news| last = Vlasic | first = Bill | date=July 10, 2009 | accessdate=September 9, 2012 | title = G.M. Vow to Slim Includes Top Ranks | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/11/business/11auto.html | newspaper=The New York Times}}{{cite news| date=July 10, 2009 | accessdate=July 10, 2009 | newspaper=The New York Times | title = A Primer on the New General Motors | last = Maynard | first = Micheline | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/11/business/11primer.html}} Through the [[Troubled Asset Relief Program]] the US Treasury invested $49.5 billion in General Motors and recovered $39 billion when it sold its shares on December 9, 2013 resulting in a loss of $10.3 billion. The Treasury invested an additional $17.2 billion into GM's former financing company, GMAC (now Ally). The shares in Ally were sold on December 18, 2014 for $19.6 billion netting $2.4 billion.{{cite news | first=Kimberly |last=Amadeo | title = Auto Industry Bailout (GM, Ford, Chrysler) | work = About News | url = http://useconomy.about.com/od/criticalssues/a/auto_bailout.htm| accessdate=July 20, 2015}}{{cite news | first=Greg |last=Gardner | title = U.S. exits Ally, auto bailout closed | work = USA Today | date=December 19, 2014 |url = https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/cars/2014/12/19/us-tarp-ally-auto-bailout/20659473/ | accessdate=July 20, 2015}} A study by the Center for Automotive Research found that the GM bailout saved 1.2 million jobs and preserved $34.9 billion in tax revenue.{{cite news | first=James R. |last=Healey | title = Government Sells Last of Its GM Shares | work = USA Today | date=December 10, 2013| url = https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/cars/2013/12/09/government-treasury-gm-general-motors-tarp-bailout-exit-sale/3925515/| accessdate=January 18, 2014}} Also in 2009 as part of the General Motors Chapter 11 Bankruptcy, the company shed several brands, closing [[Saturn Corporation|Saturn]], [[Pontiac]], and [[Hummer]], while selling [[Saab Automobile]] to Dutch automaker [[Spyker Cars|Spyker]], and emerged from a government-backed [[General Motors Chapter 11 reorganization|Chapter 11 reorganization]]. In 2010, the reorganized GM made an [[initial public offering]] that was one of the world's top five largest IPOs to-date and returned to profitability later that year.{{cite web |first=Michelle |last=Krebs |url=http://www.autoobserver.com/2009/04/good-bye-pontiac-saturn-saab-hummer.html |title=Good-Bye Pontiac, Saturn, Saab, Hummer |publisher=Autoobserver.com |date=April 27, 2009 |accessdate=December 11, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121104002602/http://www.autoobserver.com/2009/04/good-bye-pontiac-saturn-saab-hummer.html |archive-date=November 4, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}{{cite news| last = Ahlander | first = Johan | date=January 26, 2010 | title = Tiny Spyker snaps up GM's Saab for $400 million | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2010/01/26/us-gm-saab-idUSTRE60M14E20100126 | agency=Reuters}} ==Corporate governance== [[File:Detroit Renaissance-Center.jpg|thumb|[[Renaissance Center|GM World Headquarters]] in Detroit]] Based on global sales, General Motors is routinely among the world's largest automakers.{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-01-28/toyota-takes-global-auto-sales-lead-from-gm-on-disaster-recovery.html|title=Toyota Retakes Global Lead From GM on Disaster Recovery|publisher=Bloomberg L.P.|date=January 28, 2013 |accessdate=January 28, 2013}} Headquartered at the [[Renaissance Center]] in Detroit, GM employs approximately 202,000 people around the world. In 2009, General Motors sold 6.5 million cars and trucks globally; in 2010, it sold 8.39 million.{{Cite news |url=http://www.seattletimes.com/business/toyota-sold-84m-vehicles-in-2010-to-hold-top-spot/ |title=Toyota sold 8.4M vehicles in 2010 to hold top spot |date=January 24, 2011 |newspaper=The Seattle Times |accessdate=February 4, 2017}} {{As of|2017|03}}, [[Mary Barra]] is the chief executive officer (CEO) and chairman of the board and Daniel Ammann is the president.{{cite web|url=http://www.gm.com/company/leadership/corporate-officers.html |title=Corporate Officers |publisher=General Motors |accessdate=March 8, 2017}} The head of design, [[Edward T. Welburn]], was the first African American to lead a global automotive design organization, and {{as of|2014|lc=yes}} the highest ranking African American in the US motor industry.{{cite web|last1=Curry|first1=George E.|title=GM: intern advances to highest ranking Black in automobile industry|url=http://ourweekly.com/news/2014/may/01/gm-intern-advances-highest-ranking-black-automobil/?page=2|website=Our Weekly|accessdate=June 9, 2015|date=May 1, 2014}} As part of the company's advertising, Ed Whitacre announced the company's 60-day money-back guarantee and repayment of $6.7 billion loan from government ahead of schedule.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704608104575220144290856632 |title=GM To Take New Chevy Campaigns for a Spin |date=May 3, 2010 |last=Terlep |first=Sharon |newspaper=The Wall Street Journal {{Subscription required|date=July 1, 2010}}|accessdate=July 3, 2010}} On December 12, 2013, GM announced that Mary Barra, 51, executive vice president, Global Product Development, Purchasing and Supply Chain, was elected by the board of directors to become the next CEO of the company succeeding Dan Akerson on January 15, 2014. Barra also joined the GM board.{{cite pr|url=http://media.gm.com/content/media/us/en/gm/news.detail.html/content/Pages/news/emergency_news/2013/1210-gm-execs.html |title=Dan Akerson to Retire as GM CEO in January 2014 |work=GM Media |date=December 12, 2013}} From June 2009 to March 2011, the company had three chief executive officers and three chief financial officers.{{cite web |url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-03-19/gm-s-ammann-pushes-to-expand-lending-operations-he-dismantled.html |title=GM's Ammann Pushes to Expand Lending Operations He Dismantled |first=David |last=Welch |date=March 19, 2011 |work=Bloomberg Businessweek |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110326210956/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-03-19/gm-s-ammann-pushes-to-expand-lending-operations-he-dismantled.html |archivedate=March 26, 2011}}{{cite web| title=About GM: Mary T. Barra| url=http://www.gm.com/company/aboutGM/board_of_directors0/mary_barra.html| website=www.gm.com| accessdate=June 9, 2015}} ===Financial results=== The company has reported annual profits since 2010. It can carry forward previous losses to reduce tax liability on future earnings. It earned $4.7 billion in 2010. The ''Wall Street Journal'' estimated the tax break, including credits for costs related to pensions and other expenses can be worth as much as $45 billion over the next 20 years.{{cite web |url=http://ca.reuters.com/article/businessNews/idCATRE71N0ZD20110224 |title=GM Posts First Full-Year Profit Since 2004 |date=February 24, 2011 |publisher=Reuters |last=Krolicki |first=Kevin |accessdate=March 7, 2017}} In 2010, General Motors ranked second on the list with 8.5 million units produced globally.{{cite web|title=World Ranking of Manufacturers Year 2010|url=http://oica.net/wp-content/uploads/ranking-2010.pdf|format=PDF|publisher=OICA|date=August 2011 |accessdate=March 8, 2017}} In 2011, GM returned to the first place with 9.025 million units sold worldwide, corresponding to 11.9% [[market share]] of the global motor vehicle industry. The top two markets in 2011 were China, with 2,547,203 units, and the United States, with 2,503,820 vehicles sold. The Chevrolet brand was the main contributor to GM performance, with 4.76 million vehicles sold around the world in 2011, a global sales record.{{cite pr|url= http://www.greencarcongress.com/2012/01/gm-20120120.html|title= GM global sales up 7.6% in 2011 to 9.026M vehicles; China and US largest markets |publisher=Green Car Congress |author=GM Press Release |date=January 20, 2012|accessdate=January 20, 2012}} In May 2013 during a commencement speech, CEO Dan Akerson suggested that GM was on the cusp of rejoining the [[S&P 500]] index. GM was removed from the index as it approached bankruptcy in 2009.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2013-05-20/b-school-commencement-2013-gms-dan-akerson |title=B-School Commencement 2013: GM's Dan Akerson |first=Erin |last=Zlomek |work=Bloomberg BusinessWeek |date=May 20, 2013 |accessdate=November 28, 2013}} On April 24, 2014, [[CNNMoney]] reported that GM profits fell to $108 million for the first three months of 2014. GM now estimates the cost of their [[2014 General Motors recall|2014 recall]] due to faulty ignition switches, which have been linked to at least 124 deaths, at $1.5 billion.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/17/business/general-motors-ignition-suits-bankruptcy.html |title=Shell of Old G.M. Surfaces in Court Fight Over Ignition Flaw |first1=Bill |last1=Vlasic |first2=Neal E. |last2=Boudette |work=New York Times |date=August 17, 2017 |access-date=June 19, 2018}} Shares of GM were down 16% for the year before the new announcement of GM's lower profits.{{cite web|first=Chris |last=Isidore |url=http://money.cnn.com/2014/04/24/news/companies/gm-earnings-recall/index.html |title=GM's $1.3 billion recall cost wipes out profit |publisher=CNNMoney |date=April 24, 2014 |accessdate=April 24, 2014}} On January 4, 2016, ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'' reported that GM led a $1 billion equity financing in the transportation network company (TNC) [[Lyft|Lyft.com]].{{cite journal|last=Kokalitcheva|first=Kia|url=http://fortune.com/2016/01/04/lyft-funding-gm/|title=Lyft Raises $1 Billion, GM Joins As Investor And Driverless Car Partner|date=January 4, 2016|journal=Fortune |accessdate=January 19, 2016}} This was GM's first investment in the ride-sharing ventures and its reported participation ($500,000,000) in the round is considered to be indicative of its efforts towards the future of transportation, which it believes will be "connected, seamless and autonomous".{{cite journal|last=Fitzpatrick|first=Alex|url=http://time.com/4166130/general-motors-lyft/|title=Why General Motors Invested $500 Million in Lyft|journal=Time |date=January 4, 2016|accessdate=January 19, 2016}} {| class="wikitable float-left" style="text-align: right;" !Year !Revenue

|{{decrease}}1.3% |} ===North America=== [[General Motors Canada]] is a privately owned Canadian company, with the GM as the owner. The employees are not all Canadian, as some salaried personnel are from the U.S. and work for the company. GM products focus primarily on its four core divisions — Chevrolet, Cadillac, Buick, and GMC. The GM restructuring has resulted in a lower break-even point for annual sales and renewed profits.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE5502VY20090601 |title=Factbox – General Motors Bankruptcy Filing Law|agency=Reuters |date=June 1, 2009 |access-date=July 9, 2009 | first=Soyoung | last=Kim}} In mid-2005, GM announced that its corporate chrome power emblem "[[Mark of Excellence]]" would begin appearing on all recently introduced and all-new 2006 model vehicles produced and sold in North America. However, in 2009 the "New GM" reversed this, saying that emphasis on its four core divisions would downplay the GM logo.{{cite news|last=Johnson |first=Kimberly S. |url=https://www.usatoday.com/money/autos/2009-08-25-gm-logo_N.htm |title=GM To Remove Its Mark from Vehicles To Emphasize Brand |work=USA Today |date=August 27, 2009|access-date=October 12, 2009}} In May 2012, GM recorded an 18.4% market share in the U.S.{{cite web|last=Taylor|first=Tom|title=Car sales|url=http://www.autocomparison.com/|publisher=Autocomparison.com|access-date=September 21, 2012}} ===South America=== In 2008 the third largest individual country by sales was [[General Motors do Brasil|Brazil]] with some 550,000 GM vehicles sold. In that year the other South American countries Argentina, Colombia, and Venezuela sold another 300,000 GM vehicles, suggesting that the total GM sales in South America (including sales in other South American countries such as Chile, Peru, Ecuador, Bolivia, etc.) in that year were at a similar level to sales in China. {{citation needed|date=May 2017}} On April 20, 2017, General Motors announced that the [[Government of Venezuela|Venezuelan government]] had seized the General Motors Venezolana plant in [[Valencia, Carabobo|Valencia]].{{cite news |url=http://money.cnn.com/2017/04/20/news/gm-venezuela-plant-seized/ |title=GM says Venezuela has seized its car plant |first=Alanna |last=Petroff |work=CNN |location=US |date=April 20, 2017 |access-date=April 24, 2017}} ===Europe=== {{see|General Motors Europe}} Prior to their sale to [[Groupe PSA]] in 2017, [[Opel]] was the main GM brand name in Europe except in the United Kingdom, where Opel's British subsidiary, [[Vauxhall Motors|Vauxhall]], used its own "Vauxhall" brand name. The [[Chevrolet]] brand was reintroduced in Europe in 2005, selling mostly rebranded [[Daewoo Motors|Daewoo]] cars acquired by [[GM Korea]]. After having lost approximately $18B over 12 years, GM began phasing out mainstream sales of Chevrolet in Europe in late 2013, and finished by late 2015, to focus on Opel/Vauxhall.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/12/05/us-generalmotors-chevy-idUSBRE9B407W20131205|title=GM to drop Chevy brand in Europe to focus on Opel|date=December 5, 2013|accessdate=December 21, 2013|agency=Reuters}}{{cite web|url=http://media.gm.com/content/media/cn/en/gm/news.detail.html/content/Pages/news/cn/en/2013/Dec/1205_chevy_europe.html|title=GM Strengthens its European Brand Strategy|date=December 5, 2013|accessdate=December 21, 2013}} Chevrolets continue to be sold in [[Russia]] and the [[Commonwealth of Independent States]], through the [[GM Uzbekistan]] joint venture. Chevrolet still has a limited presence in Europe through imports of the [[Chevrolet Corvette|Corvette]] and [[Chevrolet Camaro|Camaro]], while Cadillac maintains a limited presence as well. In 2012, [[Groupe PSA|PSA Peugeot Citroen]] and General Motors formed an alliance, which involved General Motors acquiring seven percent of the PSA Group.{{cite news|last=Bunkley |first=Nick |title=Through Alliance, G.M. to Take a Stake in Peugeot |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/01/business/global/gm-to-take-stake-in-peugeot-in-new-alliance.html |accessdate=March 7, 2017|newspaper=The New York Times|date=February 29, 2012}} The ownership was soon divested on December 13, 2013, generating "gross proceeds of €0.25 billion."{{cite pr|url= http://media.gm.com/content/media/cn/en/gm/news.detail.html/content/Pages/news/emergency_news/2013/1212-psa-gm.html |title=GM Completes Sale of PSA Equity Stake|date=December 13, 2013 |work=GM Media [[Shanghai GM]], a joint venture with the Chinese company [[SAIC Motor]], was created on March 25, 1997. The Shanghai GM plant was officially opened on December 15, 1998, when the first Chinese-built Buick came off the assembly line. The [[SAIC-GM-Wuling Automobile]] joint-venture is also successfully selling microvans under the [[SAIC-GM-Wuling Automobile|Wuling]] brand (34 percent owned by GM). Much of General Motors' recent growth has been in the People's Republic of China, where its sales rose 66.9 percent in 2009, selling 1,830,000 vehicles and accounting for 13.4 percent of the market.{{cite web|url= http://www.4wheelsnews.com/gms-china-vehicle-sales-in-2009-rose-66.9-percent/ |author=Andrew C |title=GM's China vehicle sales in 2009 rose 66.9 percent |publisher=4wheelsnow.com |date=August 30, 2010 |accessdate=January 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20111007001352/http://www.4wheelsnews.com/gms-china-vehicle-sales-in-2009-rose-66.9-percent/ |archivedate=October 7, 2011}} [[Buick]] is strong in China, being led by the [[Buick Excelle]] subcompact. The [[Puyi|last emperor of China]] owned a Buick.{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/12801549/ns/nightly_news_with_brian_williams/ |title=In China, Buick Bucks the Trend|work=Nightly News with Brian Williams|publisher=MSNBC |date=June 15, 2006 |accessdate=October 12, 2009}} The [[Cadillac]] brand was introduced in China in 2004, starting with exports to China. GM pushed the marketing of the [[Chevrolet]] brand in China in 2005 as well, transferring [[Opel Corsa#Opel Corsa B (1993–2000)|Buick Sail]] to that brand.{{citation needed|date=February 2017}} In August 2009 the joint venture of FAW GM Light Duty Commercial Vehicle Co Ltd was formed that mainly produces Jiefang light-duty trucks.{{cite news|url=http://chinaautoweb.com/2010/09/faw-gm-increases-capacity-having-no-plan-to-introduce-gmc-yet/ |title=FAW-GM Increases Capacity, Having No Plan to Introduce GMC Yet |publisher=ChinaAutoWeb.com}} General Motors vehicle sales in China rose 28.8 percent to a record 2,351,610 units in 2010.{{cite news|url=http://media.gm.com/media/cn/en/gm/news.detail.html/content/Pages/news/cn/en/2011/Jan/0104.html |title=General Motors Sets New Sales Record in China in 2010 |date=January 5, 2011 |accessdate=November 1, 2011}} GM set up an auto research center as part of a US250 million corporate campus in Shanghai to develop '[[hybrid car|gasoline-hybrid cars]], [[electric vehicle]]s and [[alternative fuel vehicle|alternative fuels]], engines and new technologies'.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB119365251905674678 |title=GM to Invest in Green Technology in China |work=The Wall Street Journal |date=October 30, 2007|accessdate=November 7, 2010 |first=Rebecca |last=Blumenstein}} The company plans to double its sales from 2010 to about 5 million units in China by 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.autonews.com/article/20110418/GLOBAL03/304189806/gm-aims-to-double-china-sales-by-2015 |title=GM aims to double China sales by 2015 |date=April 18, 2011 |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=March 7, 2017}} [[SAIC-GM-Wuling]] established the low-cost [[Baojun]] brand to better compete with domestic rivals, [[Chery Automobile|Chery]], [[Geely Automobile|Geely]] and [[BYD Auto|BYD]] for first-time buyers of cars priced around USD10,000. It is estimated that such market in China is about 5 million vehicles a year, larger than the auto market in France and Britain combined. However, some are worried that 'local brands like [[Baojun]] could eventually become threats to their parent brands if they compete more against established models over time'. Shanghai-GM-Wuling sold 1.23 million vehicles in 2010, mainly commercial vans and trucks, of which about 700,000 units were a van called Sunshine.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/04/21/us-gm-china-idUKTRE73K07920110421 |title=GM's Baojun lineup in China could expand quickly |date=April 20, 2011 |first=Ben |last=Klayman |agency=Reuters}} GM maintains a dealership presence in Japan, called [[:ja:GMシボレー店|GM Chevrolet Shop]], previously known as ''GM Auto World Shop''.{{cite web|url=http://www.gmjapan.co.jp/|title=General Motors Japan Limited：ゼネラルモーターズ・ジャパン株式会社|publisher=|accessdate=January 19, 2016}} Current GM Japan dealerships were either former [[Saturn (automobile)|Saturn]] dealerships or [[Isuzu]] dealership locations. GM products are also currently sold by the company [[Yanase (car dealership)|Yanase Co., Ltd.]] since 1915.{{cite web|url=http://www.autonews.com/article/20080331/ZZZ_SPECIAL/504926591/yanase-opened-japan-to-western-cars |title=Yanase opened Japan to Western cars |publisher=James B. Treece |date=March 31, 2008 |accessdate=January 5, 2018}} In August 2011, GM announced plans to reactivate its plant that previously produced rebadged Chevrolet Blazer as Opel as well as Brazilian Blazer, and also build a new plant in [[Bekasi]], [[West Java]], Indonesia, which would produce 40,000 passenger cars per year for the [[Southeast Asian]] market. It is the third plant in Southeast Asia, after the [[Rayong]] plant, [[Thailand]], and the [[Hanoi]] plant, [[Vietnam]].{{cite web |url=http://www.antaranews.com/en/news/74731/general-motors-to-build-plant-in-bekasi|title=General Motors to build plant in Bekasi |date=August 12, 2011}} In October 2011, the South Korea Free Trade Agreement opened up the South Korean auto market to American made cars.{{cite news|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/usa/US-South-Korean-Presidents-Visit-Auto-Plant-131871598.html|title=Obama: 'Bailout Was Worth It'|publisher=Voice of America|date=October 14, 2011|accessdate=October 14, 2011}} GM owns (per December 31, 2011) 77.0% of its joint venture in [[South Korea]], [[GM Korea]].{{rp|p.96}} On March 11, 2013, GM opened a new 190,300 square-foot manufacturing plant in Bekasi, Indonesia.{{cite news|url=http://www.panarmenian.net/eng/news/157791/general-motors-opens-manufacturing-facility-in-Indonesia |title=New Indonesian Manufacturing Plant |publisher=Panarmenian |date=May 11, 2013|accessdate=May 11, 2013}} In February 2015, GM announced they will close the Bekasi plant by the end of June and stop production of the [[Chevrolet Sonic|Sonic]] in [[Thailand]] by mid-year.{{cite web|url=http://paultan.org/2015/02/27/general-motors-close-indonesia-plant/|title=General Motors to close Indonesian plant in June, stop Chevrolet Sonic production in Thailand|date=February 28, 2015 |publisher=paulan.org |last=Tan |first=Jonathan James |accessdate=March 2, 2015}} GM announced on May 18, 2017 that it would exit the Indian market, which it had entered for the second time in 1996. The first time was in 1928, when it became the first car maker to manufacture cars in India. GM would however continue to manufacture cars from its [[Talegaon Dhamdhere|Talegaon]], [[Maharashtra]] plant for the export market. This plant has a capacity of 1,60,000 units annually. The older Halol, Gujarat plant with a capacity for 50,000 units stopped production on April 28, 2017. It will be sold, with GM in talks with China's [[SAIC Motor|SAIC]] Motor Corporation Ltd. The India arm's domestic sales for April 2016 – March 2017 declined to 25,823 units from 32,540 the previous year and market share contracted from 1.17 percent to 0.85 percent for the same period. However, exports surged 89 percent during the same period to 70,969 units. GMTC-I, GM's technical center in Bengaluru, India will continue doing its global work. About 400 employees, 8 percent of GM's total Indian work-force, would be affected by the pull-out. Weak product line-up and below par service quality were the reasons for the poor showing by GM in India. It will also affect 10,000 employees working with about 120 Outlets/Dealership of GM in India.{{Cite web |url=http://auto.economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/passenger-vehicle/cars/gms-india-exit-the-episodic-events-of-shock-confusion-and-failure/58814677 |title=GM's India Exit: The episodic events of shock, confusion and failure - ET Auto |work=ET Auto |access-date=May 5, 2017}}{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/general-motors-to-stop-india-sales-on-rising-losses/articleshow/58742167.cms |title=General Motors to stop India sales on rising losses - Times of India |work=The Times of India |access-date=May 5, 2017}} In February 2018, comments by CEO Mary Barra that GM's Korean operations' cost strucutures had "become challenging" fuelled speculation that the company might divest GM Korea, followed by a market exit.{{Cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.fr/us/gm-could-exit-south-korea-2018-2|title=GM may be about to pull out of South Korea|website=Business Insider France|language=fr-FR|access-date=February 26, 2018}} GM is currently negotiating a $2.8 billion investment plan for its Korean operations from the South Korean government, to be dispersed over the next decade. Furthermore, the company approached the Korea Development Bank to participate in a $2.7 billion debt swap issued by its Korean subsidiary.{{cite news |url=https://www.ft.com/content/dd302b82-1789-11e8-9376-4a6390addb44| title=General Motors asks South Korea to help fund operations |work=Financial Times |location=UK |url-access=subscription |date=February 22, 2018}} According to the South Korean unit of General Motors, its domestic sales for March dropped by 58 percent, which is more than half compared to the past year. In February 2018, General Motors had said to shut down one factory and then decide what lies ahead for the remaining three plants in South Korea during rising losses there. In recent years, the US automaker pulled its Chevy brand from Europe which wedged GM Korea's exports since it was a major market for the Korean firm.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-gm-southkorea/gm-koreas-march-domestic-sales-slump-58-percent-as-restructuring-weighs-idUSKCN1H90BX|title=GM Korea's March sales dive; seeks to halt one shift at Bupyeong plant|last1=Choi|first1=Haejin|last2=Jin|first2=Hyunjoo|location=U.S.|date=April 2, 2018|access-date=April 3, 2018}} ===Africa=== [[File:World locations of General Motors factories.PNG|thumb|Global locations of General Motors' assembly factories.]] GM has a long history in [[Egypt]] which began in the 1920s with the assembly of cars and light pickup trucks for the local market. In the mid of the 1950s, GM withdrew from the Egyptian market. Some years later, the [[Ghabbour Group|Ghabbour Brothers]] began to assemble [[Cadillac]], [[Chevrolet]] and [[Buick]] models up to the 1990s. Since 1983 GM and [[Al-Monsour Automotive|Al-Monsour Automotive Company]] have owned [[General Motors Egypt]], which is currently the only manufacturer of traditional GM branded vehicles in Egypt.{{citation needed|date=February 2017}} In the 1920s ''Miller Brothers Nigeria'' was founded as an importer of commercial vehicles of the Bedford brand into the country. In 1949, the company opened its own assembly plant and operated under the name [[Niger]]/[[Nigeria]] Motors. In 1965 the plant and its distribution network was split into different companies and renamed as Federated Motors Industries. In 1991 the company was taken in by a joint venture between '''General Motors''' and UACN of [[Nigeria]].{{citation needed|date=February 2017}} Another manufacturing base of the GM for the African markets is the [[Industries Mécaniques Maghrébines]] headquartered in [[Kairouan]], [[Tunisia]], which assembles Isuzu and Mazda models for the Maghreb region.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} Formed in 1975, General Motors East Africa (GMEA) was the largest assembler of commercial vehicles in the region exporting them from Kenya to East and Central African countries including [[Uganda]], Tanzania, [[Malawi]], Rwanda and [[Burundi]]. Its facility located in [[Nairobi]] assembled a wide range of Isuzu trucks and buses including the popular Isuzu N-Series versatile light commercial vehicle, TF Series pick-ups and Isuzu bus chassis. In addition to assembly, GMEA also marketed the [[Chevrolet]] products [[Chevrolet Spark|Spark]] and Optra. Selling entire GM's 57.7 per cent stake in General Motors East Africa to Isuzu was announced on February 28, 2017.{{cite news |last1=Muchira |first1=Njiraini |title=General Motors to exit East Africa with sale of stake to Isuzu |url=http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/business/General-Motors-exit-East-Africa-sale-stake-to-Isuzu/2560-3831344-wfiylw/index.html |publisher=The EastAfrican |date=February 28, 2017 |access-date=December 24, 2017}} After finishing the sale, GMEA was renamed to Isuzu East Africa Limited, effective from August 1, 2017.{{cite news|last1=Agutu|first1=Nancy|title=General Motors changes name to Isuzu East Africa|url=https://www.the-star.co.ke/news/2017/08/02/general-motors-changes-name-to-isuzu-east-africa_c1609291|newspaper=The Star |location=Kenya |date=August 2, 2017|access-date=December 24, 2017}} General Motors began operating in South Africa in 1913 through its wholly owned subsidiary, [[General Motors South Africa]]. Following the passage of the [[Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act]] in 1986, GM was forced to divest from South Africa, and GMSA became the independent Delta Motor Corporation. GM purchased a 49% stake in Delta in 1997 following the end of [[apartheid]], and acquired the remaining 51% in 2004, reverting the company to its original name. By 2014 it was targeting the production of 50,000 cars a year but was being hampered by national labour unrest, strikes and protests.{{cite news|title=South Africa arm of General Motors hit by wage strike shuts plant|url=http://www.southafricanews.net/index.php/sid/223524973/scat/371b1b8643d479c1/ht/South-Africa-arm-of-General-Motors-hit-by-wage-strike-shuts-plant|accessdate=July 5, 2014|publisher=South Africa News.Net}} In May 2017, GM announced that it would exit the South Africa market by the end of 2017 by selling part of the business to Isuzu and look for a buyer for the rest of the business.{{cite news|last1=Snavely|first1=Brent|title=GM to stop selling vehicles in once promising India, exit South Africa|url=http://www.freep.com/story/money/2017/05/18/gm-india-south-africa/329280001/|accessdate=May 18, 2017|publisher=Detroit Free Press|date=May 18, 2017}} ===Oceania=== In New Zealand, GM was represented by locally assembled Chevrolet, Pontiac and Vauxhall cars from 1926. In 1954 sales of fully imported [[Holden]] vehicles began. New Zealand assembly of Holdens began in 1957 and through the early 1960s, Holdens replaced all Chevrolets and most Vauxhalls. Tariffs on Australian-made cars were eventually removed and local assembly plants closed by 1991. GM New Zealand was renamed Holden in 1994.{{cite book|last1=Fourie|first1=Louis|title=On a Global Mission: The Automobiles of General Motors International Volume 3|date=2016|publisher=Friesen Press|page=1137|edition=1st}} In [[Australia]], GM has been represented by the Holden brand since 1948. Chevrolets and Pontiacs were also manufactured in Australia until 1968. In 2012, GM established [[Opel]] as a niche marque in Australia and began to sell [[Opel]] cars in Australia.{{cite web|url=http://gmauthority.com/blog/2014/02/opel-models-may-be-imported-to-australia-and-sold-as-holden-no-more-german-layoffs-until-2018/ |title=Opel Models May Be Imported To Australia And Sold As Holden, No More German Layoffs Until 2018 |publisher=Gm Authority |accessdate=March 7, 2017 |last=Zimmer |first=Thomas}} However, less than twelve months later, Opel sales ceased.{{cite web|url=http://www.gizmodo.com.au/2013/08/opel-pulls-out-of-australia/ |title=Opel Pulls Out Of Australia |publisher=Gizmodo |accessdate=November 28, 2013}}{{cite web|last1=Pettendy|first1=Marton|title=Where to for Holden and Commodore?|url=https://www.motoring.com.au/where-to-for-holden-and-commodore-109876/|work=Motoring|location=Australia|accessdate=April 9, 2018|date=November 17, 2017}} On December 10, 2013, GM announced that Holden would cease manufacturing operations in Australia by the end of 2017.{{cite news | url = http://www.news.com.au/national/victoria/holden-will-cease-operations-in-2017/story-fnii5sms-1226780690797 | title = Holden will cease operations in 2017 | date=December 11, 2013 | accessdate=December 11, 2013 | publisher = news.com.au}} Holden's Australian presence now only consists of a national sales company, a parts distribution centre and a global design studio.{{cite pressrelease| url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/190829491/Holden-announces-it-will-cease-manufacturing-operations-in-Australia-by-2017 | title=Holden announces it will cease manufacturing operations in Australia by 2017 | publisher=ABC News Online via Scribd.com | date=December 10, 2013 | accessdate=December 11, 2013}} ==Motorsports== {{Unreferenced section|date=January 2016}} [[File:Jimmie Johnson 2008 Lowes Chevy Impala.jpg|thumb|upright=0.9|right|2008 [[Chevrolet Impala|Chevrolet "Impala"]] themed NASCAR race car driven by NASCAR's Jimmie Johnson]] [[File:Nicola Larini 2009 WTCC Marrakech.jpg|thumb|left|Chevrolet Cruze in the WTCC]] [[File:Corvette 4 LS.jpg|thumb|Corvette Racing Team in the [[American Le Mans Series]]]] [[File:Holden VE Commodore of James Courtney 2012.JPG|thumb|left|The [[Holden VE Commodore]] of [[James Courtney]] ([[Holden Racing Team]]) at the [[2012 Clipsal 500 Adelaide]]]] GM has participated over the years in the [[World Touring Car Championship]] (WTCC), [[24 Hours of Le Mans]], [[NASCAR]], [[SCCA]], [[Supercars Championship]], and many other world venues. GM's engines were highly successful in the [[Indy Racing League]] (IRL) throughout the 1990s, winning many races in the small [[V8 engine|V-8]] class. GM has also done much work in the [[development of electronics for GM auto racing]]. An unmodified Aurora V-8 in the Aerotech, captured 47 world records, including the record for speed endurance in the Motorsports Hall of Fame of America. Recently, the [[Cadillac V-Series]] has entered motorsports racing. GM has also used many cars in the American racing series [[NASCAR]]. Currently the [[Chevrolet Camaro|Chevrolet Camaro ZL1]] is the only entry in the series, but in the past the [[Pontiac Grand Prix]], [[Buick Regal]], [[Oldsmobile Cutlass]], [[Chevrolet Lumina]], [[Chevrolet Malibu]], [[Chevrolet Monte Carlo]], [[Chevrolet Impala]], and the [[Chevrolet SS]] were also used. GM has won a total of 40 [[Monster Energy NASCAR Cup Series]] [[List of NASCAR Manufacturers' champions|manufacturer's championships]], including 34 with Chevrolet, the most of any make in NASCAR history, 3 with Oldsmobile, 2 with Buick, and 1 with Pontiac. GM leads all other automobile manufacturers in races won in NASCAR's premier series at 1,011. Chevrolet leads individual makes with 677 wins. In Australia, there is the [[V8 Supercar]] Championship which is battled out by the two main rivals of (GM) [[Holden]] and [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]]. The current [[Holden]] Racing Team cars are based on the [[Holden Commodore]] and run a 5.0-litre V8-cylinder engine producing {{convert|635|bhp|kW|0|abbr=on}}. These cars have a top speed of {{convert|298|km/h|mi/h|0|abbr=on}} and run 0–100 km/h in 3.8 seconds. The [[Holden Racing Team]] is Australia's most successful team in Australian touring car history. In 2006 and 2007, the drivers' championship was won by the very closely linked (now defunct) [[HSV Dealer Team]]. {{clear}} ==Research and development== {{See also|General Motors Technical Center|General Motors Proving Grounds}} [[Research and development]] (R&D) at General Motors began organically as the continuation of such R&D as the various divisions (e.g., Cadillac, Buick, Olds, Oakland) were already doing for themselves before the merger. Its character was entirely empirical; it was whatever key people in each company had been competent enough to organize and pursue. [[Robert McLaughlin (industrialist)|R. S. McLaughlin]]'s Carriage Company in 1876 was designing and inventing Carriage Gear. The [[McLaughlin Motor Car Company|McLaughlin Companies]] became General Motors of Canada Limited. [[Charles F. Kettering]]'s Dayton Engineering Laboratories Company (Delco), at [[Dayton, Ohio]], was still an independent firm at this time. Its work was well known to GM central management through its relationship as a supplier and consultancy to Cadillac and Buick.{{citation needed|date=February 2017}} In 1916, Durant organized the United Motors Corporation as an amalgamation of parts suppliers, supplying GM and other OEMs but independent of GM.{{Harvnb|Sloan|1964|pp=24, 97}}. [[Alfred P. Sloan]], head of the newly acquired [[Hyatt Roller Bearing Corporation]], became United Motors' CEO. United Motors acquired Delco, and Kettering began his association with Sloan. United Motors also acquired at this time the original Remy corporation (called the Remy Electric Company), a competitor of Delco. In 1918 General Motors bought United Motors. Various entities grew out of the original Delco and Remy, including the Dayton Metal Products Corporation, the General Motors Research Corporation, the Delco Division and Remy Electric Division of GM, Delco Remy (now [[Remy International, Inc.]]), [[ACDelco]], [[Delco Electronics]], and others. Today's main successor corporation is [[Delphi Automotive]], which nowadays is an independent parent corporation.{{citation needed|date=February 2017}} The General Motors Research Corporation, at Dayton under Kettering, became a true automotive research center. During the next few decades it led the development of: * many electrical-appliance features for cars and trucks * In 1911, Charles F. Kettering, with Henry M. Leland, of Dayton Engineering Laboratories Company (DELCO) invented and filed U.S. Patent 1,150,523 for the [[Starter (engine)|first electric starter]] in America. * In 1914, Cadillac introduced the first mass-produced production V-8 in the world.{{cite web |url=http://history.gmheritagecenter.com/wiki/index.php/1914,_The_First_V-8_Engine |title=1914, The First V-8 Engine - Generations of GM |publisher=History.gmheritagecenter.com |accessdate=November 28, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203053417/http://history.gmheritagecenter.com/wiki/index.php/1914,_The_First_V-8_Engine |archive-date=December 3, 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} * In 1921, General Motors patented the use of [[Tetraethyllead]] as an antiknock agent leading to the development of higher compression engines resulting in more power and efficiency even though much later it was realized that lead in gasoline was harmful to various biological organisms including humans. ASM'', Vol. '''26''', 1938, p 574-606. of GM invented the Jominy end-quench test for [[hardenability]] of carbon steel, a breakthrough in [[heat treating]] still in use today as [[ASTM]] A255.[http://www.astm.org/Standards/A255.htm ASTM A255-10], Standard Test Methods for Determining Hardenability of Steel, ASTM International, West Conshohocken, PA. * In 1939, GM introduced the world's first automatic transmission the Hydra-matic for the 1940 Oldsmobile and would be adopted by the auto industry later.{{cite web |url=http://history.gmheritagecenter.com/wiki/index.php/1939,_The_First_Fully_Automatic_Transmission |title=1939, The First Fully Automatic Transmission - Generations of GM |publisher=History.gmheritagecenter.com |accessdate=November 28, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203054501/http://history.gmheritagecenter.com/wiki/index.php/1939,_The_First_Fully_Automatic_Transmission |archive-date=December 3, 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} * In 1962, GM introduced the first turbo charged engine in the world for a car in the Oldsmobile Cutlass Turbo-Jetfire.{{cite web |url=http://history.gmheritagecenter.com/wiki/index.php/1962,_The_First_Production_Turbocharged_Engine |title=1962, The First Production Turbocharged Engine - Generations of GM |publisher=History.gmheritagecenter.com |accessdate=November 28, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203053103/http://history.gmheritagecenter.com/wiki/index.php/1962,_The_First_Production_Turbocharged_Engine |archive-date=December 3, 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} * In 1971, the [[Lunar Roving Vehicle|Lunar Rover]], a partnership between GM's Delco Defense Electronics Division and [[Boeing]] traversed the surface of the Moon.{{cite web|last1=Rechtin|first1=Mark|title=GM's most widely traveled 1971 model was built for the moon |url=http://www.autonews.com/article/20080914/OEM06/309149969/gms-most-widely-traveled-1971-model-was-built-for-the-moon |accessdate=January 9, 2017|date=September 14, 2008|publisher=Automotive News}} * In 1972, GM produced the first rear wheel Anti-lock brake system in the world for two of their cars: the Toronado and Eldorado.{{cite web |url=http://history.gmheritagecenter.com/wiki/index.php/1972,_First_Automotive_Anti-lock_Brake_System_(ABS) |title=1972, First Automotive Anti-lock Brake System (ABS) - Generations of GM |publisher=History.gmheritagecenter.com |accessdate=November 28, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203054131/http://history.gmheritagecenter.com/wiki/index.php/1972,_First_Automotive_Anti-lock_Brake_System_(ABS) |archive-date=December 3, 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} * In 1984, Robert Lee{{cite web |last=Lee |first=Robert |title=Iron-Rare Earth-Boron Permanent US Patent # 4,792,367 |url=https://www.google.com/patents/US4792367 |date=December 20, 1988}} of GM invented the [[Neodymium magnet|Fe14Nd2B permanent magnet]], fabricated by rapid solidification. * [[dichlorodifluoromethane]] refrigerant for [[HVAC]] and [[refrigeration]] applications (Freon, R-12; recognized today as a bad idea environmentally [being a [[chlorofluorocarbon]] (CFC)], but a technological wonder of its day) * commercially practical [[two-stroke diesel engine]]s * better transmissions for track-laying vehicles * many other advancements Although GM R&D (as it is known in colloquial shorthand) began as an organization largely built around one man (Kettering), it eventually evolved into a more modern organization whose path is shaped by individuals but not dominated entirely by any of them. World War II was a turning point wherein military affairs, after mingling with the technologies of applied science for some 80 years, first started to become fundamentally reinvented by them. Civilian life, too, changed in this direction. By the 1950s, corporations such as GM and many others were facing a new era of R&D, different from earlier ones. Less about genius inventors and individual inventions, and more about organizational progress and integrated systems, it raised new questions about where the [[capital (economics)|capital]] for R&D would come from in an era of limitless demand for R&D (although not necessarily for production). [[Alfred P. Sloan|Alfred Sloan]], longtime CEO of GM (1920s to 1960s), discussed in his memoir (also considered a seminal management treatise) the relationships between government, academia, and private industry in the areas of basic science and applied science, in light of this new era.{{Harvnb|Sloan|1964|pp=249–252}}. The views he laid out reflected (and influenced) wide consensus on these relationships that persists largely to today.{{citation needed|date=February 2017}} Today, GM R&D, headquartered in [[Warren, Michigan]], is a network of six laboratories, six science offices, and collaborative relationships in over twelve countries including working relationships with universities, government groups, suppliers, and other partners from across the globe.{{Cite web |url=https://www.phmsociety.org/node/244|title=General Motors Global R&D |publisher=Prognostics and Health Management Society |location=US |year=2013 |access-date=August 30, 2018}} On September 7, 2014, at the Intelligent Transport Systems World Congress in Detroit GM disclosed it would be introducing auto-pilot features into certain 2017 models of its cars, which would go on sale in 2016. The "super cruise" or vehicle-to-vehicle V2V technology is likely to be first introduced to the Cadillac range, enabling drivers to switch in and out of semi-automated mode.{{cite news|title=GM joins race for hands free driving by 2016|url=http://www.detroitnews.net/index.php/sid/225509181|date=September 8, 2014|accessdate=September 8, 2014|publisher=Detroit News.Net}} In December 2016, General Motors announced it would begin testing self-driving vehicles on public roads in Michigan, after Gov. Rick Snyder signed a package of bills legalizing the operation of autonomous vehicles.{{Cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2016/12/15/gm-self-driving-cars-michigan/|title=GM's Self-Driving Cars Are Coming to Michigan's Roads, Immediately|date=December 15, 2016 |work=Fortune |accessdate=December 16, 2016}} In March 2016, General Motors bought Cruise Automation, a San Francisco self-driving vehicle start-up, to develop self-driving cars that could be used in ride-sharing fleets.{{Cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-gm-cruiseautomation-idUSKCN0WD1ND |title=GM buys Cruise Automation to speed self-driving car strategy |first=Joseph |last=White |newspaper=Reuters |date=March 11, 2016 |accessdate=March 13, 2016}}{{Cite web |url=http://gadgets.ndtv.com/others/news/gm-buys-self-driving-technology-startup-cruise-812784|title=GM Buys Self-Driving Technology Startup Cruise|website=NDTV Gadgets360.com |date=March 12, 2016 |accessdate=March 13, 2016}} In October 2017, General Motors acquired Strobe, a solid state [[LIDAR]] company. Strobe's prototypes produce brief "chirps" of frequency-modulated (FM) laser light, where the frequency within each chirp varies linearly. Measuring the phase and frequency of the echoing chirp allows the system to directly measure both the distance and the velocity of objects in the road ahead. Strobe, Cruise and GM will work together to develop the technology for future self-driving cars.{{cite web |title=How we're solving the LIDAR problem |url=https://medium.com/kylevogt/how-were-solving-the-lidar-problem-8b4363ff30db |website=Medium |first=Kyle |last=Vogt |date=October 9, 2017 |access-date=October 11, 2017}}{{cite news |title=GM Cruise Snaps Up Solid-State Lidar Pioneer Strobe Inc |url=https://spectrum.ieee.org/cars-that-think/transportation/self-driving/gm-cruise-snaps-up-solidstate-lidar-pioneer-strobe-inc |first=Mark |last=Harris |publisher=IEEE |date=October 9, 2017 |access-date=October 11, 2017}} In November 2017 Two self-driving Chevy Bolt EV cars were seen during a media event by Cruise Automation, GM's [[autonomous car]] unit, in San Francisco, California, U.S.. The automaker is already operating self-driving Chevy Bolts in San Francisco as part of a beta test run by the company's subsidiary. The firm announced an initial investment of $275 Million initially, followed by $2 Billion within the year.{{Cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-gm-autonomous/honda-to-invest-2-75-billion-in-gms-self-driving-car-unit-idUSKCN1MD1GW |title=Honda to invest $2.75 billion in GM's self-driving car unit |first1=Nick |last1=Carey |first2=Paul |last2=Lienert |work=Reuters |location=US |date=October 3, 2018 |access-date=October 4, 2018}}{{Cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-10-03/gm-s-cruise-draws-2-75-billion-from-honda-in-self-driving-pact |title=GM's Cruise Draws $2.75 Billion From Honda in Self-Driving Pact |first=Davod |last=Welch |work=Bloomberg |location=US |date=October 3, 2018 |access-date=October 4, 2018}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/gm-gets-honda-to-invest-2-75-billion-in-its-self-driving-car-unit-cruise/ |title=GM gets Honda to invest $2.75 billion in its self-driving car unit |first=Kate |last=Gibson |work=CBS |location=US |date=October 3, 2018 |access-date=October 4, 2018}} ==Small car sales== [[File:Chevrolet Aveo RS concept front.jpg|thumb|Chevrolet Aveo Concept, later went into production as the Chevrolet Aveo, UK and the Chevrolet Sonic, US]] From the 1920s onward, General Motors always maintained an internal dialog about what its economy-car and small-car policies should be.{{Harvnb|Sloan|1964|pp=313–339}}, Chapter 18, "The corporation overseas".{{Harvnb|Sloan|1964|pp=440–442}}. The economy and size considerations often naturally overlapped, although a strong distinction was always drawn in the 20th century between policies for the U.S. market and policies for other markets. Economy (in some form) always had good demand anywhere, but its definition in the U.S. was long considered different from that in other markets. In this view, "economy" in the U.S. did not mean "small" in the sense of what qualified as "small" outside the U.S. The policy discussion often focused on topics like the higher demand for truly small cars in non-U.S. markets than in the U.S., and whether it made more sense to import a car into a certain country or to build it domestically within that country, either as some variant of [[knock-down kit|knockdown]] or with truly extensive domestic sourcing. GM's acquisitions of Vauxhall Motors Ltd (UK, 1925) and Adam Opel AG (Germany, 1929), rather than starting new domestic companies to compete against them, were based on analyses that convinced GM managers that acquiring an existing domestic manufacturer was a better business decision. Although GM since the 1920s has always offered economy models in the U.S. market (relative to that market's definition in any given decade), and had done research and development in the 1940s and 1950s in preparation for any potential rise of strong demand for truly small cars in the U.S. market, it has also been criticized over the decades for not doing enough to promote fuel efficiency in the U.S. market in the 1970s through 1990s. GM's response has been that it has always responded to market demands, and that most Americans, despite anything they said to the contrary, did not actually demand (at purchasing-decision time) small size or fuel efficiency in their vehicles to any great or lasting extent. Although some U.S. consumers flocked temporarily to the ideal of fuel economy whenever fuel supply crises arose (such as 1973 and 1979), they flocked equally enthusiastically to SUVs when cheap fuel of the 1980s and 1990s temporarily shielded them from any downside to these choices.{{citation needed|date=February 2017}} Since the return of high fuel prices in the 2000s and 2010s, GM's interest in truly small-car programs for the U.S. market has been renewed. As part of General Motors Company development, GM revived one of its idled U.S. factories for the production of a small car in [[Orion, Michigan]], with the creation of 1,200 American jobs. This will be the first time that GM produced a [[sub compact car]] in the United States since the [[Chevrolet Chevette]] ended production in 1986. This retooled plant will be capable of building 160,000 cars annually, including both small and compact vehicles. Production started in late 2011 with the [[Chevrolet Sonic]].{{cite news|last1=Motavalli|first1=Jim|title=GM's Big Bet on the Made-in-the-USA Sonic Subcompact|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/gms-big-bet-on-the-made-in-the-usa-sonic-subcompact/|accessdate=March 7, 2017|publisher=CBS News|date=July 14, 2011}} ==Environmental initiatives== [[File:DCA 06 2012 Chevy Volt 4035.JPG|thumb|The 2011 [[Chevrolet Volt]], a plug-in electric vehicle.]] [[File:2016 Chevrolet Volt NAIAS 2015 trimmed.jpg|thumb|[[Chevrolet Volt (second generation)|Second generation Chevrolet Volt]].]] General Motors has published principles regarding the environment and maintains an extensive website to inform the public. In 2008, General Motors committed to engineering half of its manufacturing plants to be landfill-free. In order to achieve its landfill-free status, production waste is recycled or reused in the manufacturing process.{{cite pr|title=GM Surpasses Landfill-Free Facilities Commitment|url=http://media.gm.com/media/us/en/gm/home.detail.html/content/Pages/news/us/en/2010/Dec/1213_landfill.html|website=GM.com |accessdate=March 8, 2017}} [[List of rooftop photovoltaic installations|The world's largest rooftop solar power installation]] was installed at General Motors Spanish Zaragoza Manufacturing Plant in fall 2008. The Zaragoza solar installation has about {{convert|2000000|sqft|m2}} of roof at the plant and contains about 85,000 solar panels. The installation was created, owned and operated by Veolia Environment and Clairvoyant Energy, who lease the rooftop area from General Motors.[http://www.gm.com/corporate/responsibility/environment/news/2008/solar_070808.jsp GM Adding World's Largest Rooftop Solar Power Installation to Zaragoza Plant ].''GM.com'' (July 8, 2008). Retrieved December 4, 2010.Reuters UK (July 8, 2008).[http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKCAS84477520080708 GM Europe puts solar roof on Spanish plant]. Retrieved December 4, 2010. In 2011, General Motors also invested $7.5 million in solar-panel provider Sunlogics, which will install solar panels on GM facilities.VentureBeat. [https://venturebeat.com/2011/07/28/general-motors-sunlogics-funding/ General Motors invests $7.5M in rooftop-solar company Sunlogics]." GM has long worked on [[alternative fuel vehicle|alternative-technology vehicles]], and has led the industry with ethanol-burning [[flexible-fuel vehicle]]s that can run on either [[E85]] (ethanol) or gasoline. The company was the first to use [[turbocharger]]s and was an early proponent of [[V6 engine]]s in the 1960s, but quickly lost interest as [[muscle car]] popularity increased. They demonstrated{{cite web |url=http://www.conklinsystems.com/firebird/mlife.php |title=America's First Turbine Car |publisher=Conklin Systems |date=November 21, 1952 |accessdate=December 4, 2010}} [[gas turbine]] vehicles powered by [[kerosene]], an area of interest throughout the industry, but abandoned the alternative engine configuration in view of the [[1973 oil crisis]]. In the 1970s and 1980s, GM pushed the benefits of [[diesel engine]]s and [[cylinder deactivation]] technologies with disastrous results due to poor durability in the [[Oldsmobile]] diesels and drivability issues in the [[Cadillac]] V8-6-4 variable-cylinder engines. In 1987, GM, in conjunction with [[AeroVironment]], built the [[Sunraycer]], which won the inaugural [[World Solar Challenge]] and was a showcase of advanced technology. Much of the technology from Sunraycer found its way into the Impact prototype electric vehicle (also built by Aerovironment) and was the predecessor to the [[General Motors EV1]].{{cite web|title=General Motors 'SunRaycer'|url=http://americanhistory.si.edu/collections/search/object/nmah_1299505|website=Smithsonian Institution|publisher=Smithsonian Institution|accessdate=March 8, 2017}} GM supported a compromise version of the [[Corporate Average Fuel Economy]] (CAFE) standard increase from {{convert|27|to|35|mpgus|L/100 km mpgimp|abbr=on}}, the first such increase in over 20 years.{{cite web|url=http://automotiveindustry-asiri.blogspot.com/2009/11/alternative-propulsion-initiatives.html |title=Alternative propulsion initiatives |publisher=Automotive Industry |date=November 10, 2009 |accessdate=May 31, 2012}}{{Unreliable source?|reason=blog|sure=y|date=January 2017}} GM announced they will introduce more Volt-based plug-in hybrids.{{citation needed|date=February 2017}} The company has publicly announced that it is committed to invest heavily in [[Electric car|electric cars]]. In October 2017, GM's executive vice president of global development, [[Mark Reuss]], announced that GM's vehicle lineup would feature 20 electric car models by 2023.{{Cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-10-02/gm-pledges-electric-future-with-20-all-electric-models-by-2023 |title=GM Plans 20 All-Electric Models by 2023 |last=Welch |first=David |work=Bloomberg |date=October 2, 2017 |access-date=May 4, 2018}}{{Cite news |url=https://www.engadget.com/2017/10/02/gm-20-electric-car-models-by-2023/ |title=GM will have 20 electric car models on the road by 2023 |last=Baldwin |first=Roberto |date=October 2, 2017 |work=Engadget |access-date=May 4, 2018}} ===Hybrid electric vehicles=== [[File:Chevrolet Tahoe hybrid MLB All Star Game edition at 67 St NYC.jpg|thumb|Chevrolet Tahoe Hybrid]] In May 2004, GM delivered the world's first full-sized hybrid pickups, the 1/2-ton Silverado/Sierra. The production Chevrolet Volt was available in late 2010 as a 2011 model with limited availability.{{cite web |title=Sustainable transportation based on electric vehicle concepts: a brief overview |url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/224880220|last1=Eberle|first1=Ulrich|first2=Rittmar|last2=von Helmolt |publisher=Royal Society of Chemistry |date=May 14, 2010| accessdate=June 8, 2010}} GM delivered the first Volt during December 2010.[https://web.archive.org/web/20101216022522/http://media.gm.com/content/media/us/en/news/news_detail.brand_gm.html/content/Pages/news/us/en/2010/Dec/1213_volt "Chevrolet Volts Begin Shipping to Dealerships"] Archived from [http://media.gm.com/content/media/us/en/news/news_detail.brand_gm.html/content/Pages/news/us/en/2010/Dec/1213_volt the original] on December 16, 2010 The GM Magic Bus is a hybrid-powered bus.{{cite web|title=GM's Hybrid Propulsion System for Transit Buses |url=http://www.gm.com/company/gmability/adv_tech/300_hybrids/index_bus.html |accessdate=May 22, 2007|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070526073022/http://www.gm.com/company/gmability/adv_tech/300_hybrids/index_bus.html |archivedate=May 26, 2007}} ===All-electric vehicles=== [[File:EV1 (6).jpg|thumb|The [[electric car|all-electric]] [[General Motors EV1]] was introduced in California in 1996.]] [[File:Chevrolet Bolt EV SAO 2016 8894.jpg|thumb|The [[Chevrolet Bolt EV]] was released in California by late 2016.]] {{Further|Who Killed the Electric Car?#Batteries}} General Motors was the first company (in the modern era) to release an all-electric automobile. In 1990, GM debuted the "Impact" concept car at the Los Angeles Auto Show. It was the first car with zero-emissions marketed in the US in over three decades. The Impact was eventually produced as the [[EV1]] for the 1996 model year. It was available through dealers located in only a few regions (e.g., California, Arizona, Georgia). Vehicles were leased, rather than sold, to individuals. In 1999 GM decided to cease production of the vehicles. When the individual leases had expired, they declined to renew the leases or allow the lessors to purchase them. All of the EV1s were eventually returned to General Motors and, with the exception of a few which were donated to museums, all were destroyed. The documentary film ''[[Who Killed the Electric Car?]]'' covered the EV1 story.{{cite news |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/09/06/sunday/main3239838.shtml |title=Could the electric car save us? |publisher=CBS News |location=US |date=September 6, 2007 |access-date=June 24, 2017}} The EV1's cancellation had disappointed supporters of electric vehicles. GM also established an automotive battery laboratory in Michigan.{{cite web|url=http://apps1.eere.energy.gov/news/news_detail.cfm/news_id=12177 |title=EERE News: GM to Buy Lithium-Ion Batteries Cells for the Chevy Volt from LG Chem |publisher=Apps1.eere.energy.gov |date=January 14, 2009 |accessdate=June 1, 2009}} GM will be responsible for battery management systems and power electronics, thermal management, as well as the pack assembly. An existing GM facility at Brownstown Township was chosen to be upgraded as battery pack plant. LG Chem's U.S. subsidiary, Compact Power of Troy, Michigan, has been building the prototype packs for the development vehicles and will continue to provide integration support and act as a liaison for the program.{{citation needed|date=February 2017}} ===Hydrogen initiative=== [[File:DSCN1474.JPG|thumb|[[General Motors Sequel|Sequel]], a fuel cell-powered vehicle from GM]] The 1966 GM Electrovan is credited with being the first hydrogen [[fuel cell]] car ever produced.{{cite book |last=Léon|first=Aline|date=2008 |title=Hydrogen Technology: Mobile and Portable Applications |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JuGJHXj_jcwC&pg=PA287 |location= |publisher=Springer Science+Business Media |page=287 |isbn=9783540699255 |accessdate=August 23, 2014}} Though fuel cells have been around since the early 1800s, General Motors was the first to use a fuel cell, supplied by Union Carbide, to power the wheels of a vehicle with a budget of "millions of dollars".{{cite web|url=http://www.hydrogencarsnow.com/gm-electrovan.htm |title=1966 GM Electrovan - First Hydrogen Fuel Cell Vehicle |publisher=Hydrogencarsnow.com |accessdate=December 11, 2013}}{{cite news|last1=Truett|first1=Richard|title=Fuel cell expert takes the long view|url=http://www.autonews.com/article/20020916/SUB/209160740/fuel-cell-expert-takes-the-long-view|accessdate=March 27, 2017|work=The Automotive News|date=September 16, 2002}} In 2002, it was reported that GM spent about $100 million a year in research and development of fuel cell vehicle. In June 2007, Larry Burns, vice president of research and development, said he's not yet willing to say exactly when hydrogen vehicles would be mass-produced, but he said it should happen before 2020, the year many experts have predicted. He said "I sure would be disappointed if we weren't there" before 2020.{{cite web |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/2007/06/15/gm-executive-says-hydrogen-powered-cars-could-be-on-road-in-several-test-markets-in-6-years/ |title=GM executive says hydrogen-powered cars could be on road in several test markets in 6 years |newspaper=Mercury News |agency=Associated Press |date=June 15, 2007}} On July 2, 2013, GM and Honda announced a partnership to develop fuel cell systems and hydrogen storage technologies for the 2020 time frame. GM and Honda are leaders in fuel cell technology, ranking No. 1 and No. 2, respectively, in total fuel cell patents filed between 2002 and 2012, with more than 1,200 between them according to the Clean Energy Patent Growth Index.{{citation needed|date=February 2017}} ===Flexible-fuel vehicles=== [[File:Chevrolet Impala FlexFuel 34 MIA 12 2008 with logo.jpg|thumb|right|E85 FlexFuel [[Chevrolet Impala]] LT 2009 (USA).]] GM produces several [[flexible-fuel vehicle]]s that can operate on [[E85]] [[ethanol fuel]] or gasoline, or any blend of both. Since 2006 GM started featuring a bright yellow gas cap to remind drivers of the E85 capabilities.{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/money/autos/environment/2007-05-05-ethanolvehicles_N.htm| title= 'Flex-fuel' Vehicles Touted|work=USA Today | first=Ken |last=Thomas | date=May 7, 2007 | accessdate=September 15, 2008}} GM is the leader in E85 flex fuel vehicles, with over 6 million FlexFuel vehicles on the road in the U.S. In 2010, GM pledged to have more than half of their annual vehicle production be E85 or [[biodiesel]] capable by 2012.[http://media.gm.com/media/us/en/gm/news.detail.html/content/Pages/news/us/en/2010/May/0505_flexfuel.html General Motors Statement on Flex-Fuel Vehicle Pledge] General Motors. May 5, 2010. Retrieved September 9, 2012. The program involved 5 designers, each lending their artistic talents to customize 5 different vehicles. [[Nicole Miller]], [[Richard Tyler (designer)|Richard Tyler]], [[Anna Sui]], [[Todd Oldham]] and [[Mark Eisen]] were tasked with transforming a [[Cadillac STS]], [[Buick Riviera]], [[GMC Yukon]], [[Oldsmobile Bravada]] and [[Chevrolet Camaro]] Z28, respectively. The cars were then auctioned with the proceeds presented to the [[Nina Hyde]] Center at the Greater Los Angeles Auto Show in 1997.{{cite pr |url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/general-motors-and-fashion-industry-target-breast-cancer-through-conceptcure-77678762.html |title=General Motors and Fashion Industry Target Breast Cancer Through Concept:Cure |date=October 21, 1997 |website=prnewswire.com |publisher=General Motors Corporation |accessdate=October 28, 2015 |quote=''the program enlisted the support of fashion designers Nicole Miller, Richard Tyler, Anna Sui, Todd Oldham and Mark Eisen to lend their artistic talents to GM'S Cadillac STS, Buick Riviera, GMC Yukon, Oldsmobile Bravada and Chevrolet Camaro Z28, respectively.
